Working With brms

Source: vignettes/brms.Rmd
brms.Rmd
library(shredder)
library(brms)

Generate Data

group <- rep(c("treat", "placebo"), 
             each = 30)

symptom_post <- c(
  rnorm(30, mean = 1, sd = 2), 
  rnorm(30, mean = 0, sd = 1)
)

dat1 <- data.frame(group, symptom_post)

Run Model

fit <- brm(bf(symptom_post ~ group, sigma ~ group), 
           data = dat1, 
           family = gaussian(),
           seed = 1234)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 4000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI    Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept        -0.02987   0.18573 -0.39135  0.33840 1.00046     4606     2969
sigma_Intercept   0.02678   0.13760 -0.22230  0.32068 1.00009     3791     2651
grouptreat        1.02893   0.46830  0.12135  1.95375 1.00244     2900     2431
sigma_grouptreat  0.82399   0.19262  0.44453  1.20981 1.00150     3952     2657

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Select first 100 Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_slice <- fit%>%stan_slice(1:100)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1100; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 400

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI    Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept        -0.03073   0.18667 -0.36567  0.35834 1.00393      587      293
sigma_Intercept   0.01605   0.14156 -0.23207  0.30278 1.00354      344      309
grouptreat        1.05254   0.44522  0.27012  1.96539 1.00216      363      329
sigma_grouptreat  0.82547   0.20109  0.40933  1.24597 1.01326      325      219

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_slice%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Thin 25% of Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_thin <- fit%>%
  stan_thin_frac(0.25)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1250; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 1000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI    Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept        -0.01856   0.18550 -0.36952  0.35916 1.00409      863      915
sigma_Intercept   0.02476   0.13872 -0.22832  0.33578 0.99946     1017      809
grouptreat        0.99916   0.48929  0.08132  1.97457 0.99983      935      972
sigma_grouptreat  0.82824   0.19470  0.43033  1.21142 0.99851      995     1035

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_thin%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional

fit_filter <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1013; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 52

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI    Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept        -0.24934   0.19518 -0.70611  0.02528 1.18297       30       62
sigma_Intercept   0.05607   0.15675 -0.19553  0.34913 1.02043       73       48
grouptreat        2.18870   0.14220  2.01267  2.55671 1.04399       67       48
sigma_grouptreat  0.82625   0.22079  0.43023  1.20728 1.02601       62       62

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional Subset Chain

fit_filter_chain <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)%>%
  stan_retain(chains = 1)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 1 chains, each with iter = 1013; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 13

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI    Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept        -0.36244   0.10040 -0.52520 -0.22373 1.05009       12       13
sigma_Intercept   0.08890   0.13778 -0.08819  0.30702 1.18685        7       13
grouptreat        2.23651   0.10860  2.05442  2.35555 1.09082       12       13
sigma_grouptreat  0.79669   0.21255  0.48546  1.09190 1.37166        6       13

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter_chain%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)
